list.title: Question 1
list.content:
Which statement is not true about the genome?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The human genome is organised into chromosomes.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Each liver cell contains a full copy of the genome.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Organisms of the same species share most of their genome.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ All the information carried by the genome is expressed in each cell.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Not all genes are expressed in each cell. Only the necessary genes are expressed based on the specialised function of the cell. Choice D is not a true statement, and so is the correct answer.
The genome is all the genetic information of an organism, including the genes and non-coding DNA. In humans, the genome is organised into linear chromosomes in the nucleus, and circular chromosomes in the mitochondria. Choice A is a true statement and so an incorrect answer. Organisms of the same species have most of their genome in common; however, variations give rise to some diversity between individuals. Choice C is a true statement and so an incorrect answer. Each cell in a multicellular organism typically contains a full copy of the genome, including liver cells, an exception is red blood cells as they do not have a nucleus. Choice B is a true statement and so an incorrect answer.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The scientific name for the little spotted kiwi is Apteryx owenii. Which of the species below is most closely related to the little spotted kiwi?
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9878cab2-bbf6-4ef3-affc-520f8a700b10/images/6faa3925-6492-47de-90a7-925e1e8a2859/BI1227.png)


[Source: Adapted from Lapsley Miller, J. (2023, August 28). Little Spotted Kiwi. Wikipedia. Retrieved September 13, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_spotted_kiwi.  Copyright under CC BY-SA 4.0]



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Apteryx australis
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Little spotted pardalote
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Owenii apteryx
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Neognathae owenii
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Species names are given using the binomial system, where the genus comes first, and the species follows. Species with the same genus have similar traits and are closely related;  Choice A  is correct.
Choice B  is incorrect as it is not a scientific name, so conveys no information about the relatedness of species. Choice C is incorrect as it is just a reversal of the scientific name of the little spotted kiwi, and is in a different genus. Choice D  is incorrect as it is not in the same genus as the little spotted kiwi.

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
What is the best definition for a species?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of individuals living in a defined area.
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of individuals of the same species living and interacting with one another in a given area.
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of individuals living in a given area and interacting within the environment.
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ A group of individuals that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
A group of individuals living in a defined area is not a biological definition (Choice A).  A group of individuals of the same species living in a given area at the same time who are interacting with each other is a population (Choice B) and the environment in which they live is a habitat (Choice C). It is only when they can interbreed to produce fertile offspring that they can be considered a species. (Choice D).

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The table shows the nucleotide base sequence and genome size (number of base pairs, bp) for different species.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/129076a1-8fb2-48be-8b41-09d19f5d4455/images/e50f84c7-31b6-4770-bdd6-a3ae9bb089f4/BI0840.png)


[©Revision Village 2023. ]
Which conclusion can be drawn, based on the table and your own knowledge?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genome size is proportional to the size of the species.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The more closely related two species are, the more similar their base sequences.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Humans have more genes than chimpanzees, mice and horses.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The base sequence in the table for humans and chimpanzees is the same, therefore they have an identical genetic code.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Species that share a recent common ancestor, such as humans and chimpanzees, are more likely to have similar base sequences. Over time, as species diverge and evolve, mutations accumulate in their base sequences. The longer two species have been separated from their common ancestor, the more mutations will have accumulated in their genomes. Therefore, species that are closely related have fewer accumulated mutations and more similar base sequences (Choice B).
Choice A is incorrect because genome size is not necessarily proportional to the size of the species. The genome size can vary significantly even among organisms of similar size, and organisms with similar-sized genomes, such as the horse and mouse vary greatly in size. Choice C is incorrect because it is possible to have a larger genome size with a comparable, or even smaller, number of genes, depending on the amount of non-coding DNA and repetitive sequences present in the genome. Humans have a larger genome but a similar number of genes to the chimpanzee, mouse and horse. Choice D is incorrect because there is a difference of one nucleotide base in the table between humans and chimpanzees. The genome of humans and chimpanzees is similar but not the same.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
What is the purpose of a biological dichotomous key?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ To identify how closely organisms are related
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ To decide on the binomial name of an organism
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ To identify species
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ To find the last common ancestor of two species
list.markScheme:
C
$\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: 
Dichotomous keys are tools that are used to identify different species based on their physical characteristics; Choice C  is correct.
Choice A  is incorrect, as dichotomous keys are not used to identify how closely organisms are related. Choice B is incorrect as dichotomous keys may help in identifying the binomial name of an organism, but they do not help with the decision of what to name a species. Choice D  is incorrect, as dichotomous keys do not allow scientists to identify the last common ancestor of two species.

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
Biologists use the binomial naming system to name every organism on the planet. The binomial name for the platypus is Ornithorhynchus anatinus. Which statement(s) below are true for the binomial naming system and the platypus?


- I. $\hspace{1em}$	The genus for the platypus is   Ornithorhynchus.
- II. $\hspace{.7em}$	The binomial naming system is based on an international agreement
between scientists.
- III. $\hspace{.4em}$ 	The name,   Ornithorhynchus anatinus is unique to platypus species.




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$	I and II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$	II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$	I, II and III
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All three statements are correct. The first part of the binomial name is the genus, the second part is the species which is unique to platypus species. The binomial system and binomial names are agreed between biologists at international congresses.

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Which of the following is the correct format for species names according to the binomial naming system?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + Species
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + species
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + species
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Genus + Species
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because only the genus name should be capitalised, it should come before the species name, and both should be in italics. Choices A and D are incorrect because only the genus name should be capitalised. Choice B is incorrect, as the genus and species name should be in italics.

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
Whole genome sequencing has been used to sequence the genomes of many species. Which of the following are potential future uses of whole genome sequencing?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Identifying disease-causing alleles.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Sequencing the genomes of bacteria and fungi.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Advancing personalised medicine.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Identifying evolutionary relationships between species.
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because personalised medicine is a potential future application of whole genome sequencing. While it is not yet widely available, the continued study of individual genomes could lead to treatments tailored to an individual’s genetic profile, improving the effectiveness of medical interventions.
Choice A is incorrect because whole genome sequencing has already been used to identify disease-causing alleles which is improving understanding of genetic diseases.
Choice B is incorrect because whole genome sequencing is currently being used to sequence the genomes of disease-causing bacteria and viruses.
Choice D is incorrect because whole genome sequencing of a range of species is currently being used to identify evolutionary relationships and common ancestors; it is not a novel use.

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
Which of the following would provide evidence for two individuals belonging to different species?


- I.Differences in genome base sequenceII.Differences in genome sizeIII.Differences in chromosome number




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ III only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because only statement III is evidence of organisms being different species. Organisms of the same species will normally have the same number of chromosomes, except in the case of some genetic conditions such as Down syndrome in humans. So organisms having different numbers of chromosomes is evidence for them being separate species. Statements I and II can both vary within a species due to mutations.

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
Which of the following is true for the biological species concept?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Organisms within the same species can interbreed to produce fertile offspring
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Organisms within the same species can interbreed to produce infertile offspring
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Species are groups of organisms with shared traits
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Species are groups of organisms without shared traits
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
According to the biological species concept, a species is a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring. Choice A is correct. Choice B is incorrect as it refers to infertile offspring. Choices C and D are incorrect because they refer to the morphological species concept.

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
What determines the overall size of a eukaryotic genome?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ The number of genes
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ The number of chromosomes
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ The amount of protein
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ The total amount of DNA
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The number of genes contributes to the overall size of the genome, but it is not the sole determinant. Eukaryotic genomes contain a significant amount of noncoding DNA.  The amount of this non-coding DNA is a major contributing factor to the overall size of a eukaryotic genome.  Choice A is incorrect.
Chromosomes vary greatly in the number of genes and noncoding DNA they contain. Simply knowing the number of chromosomes in a genome does little to describe the size of the genome.  Choice B is incorrect.
Choice C is incorrect because a genome is a measure of only the amount of DNA and does not consider protein.  
Choice D is the correct choice because it is the total amount of DNA in a genome that determines the size of that genome, regardless of the function of the DNA.

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
The okapi looks like a small-sized giraffe and has stripes that resemble the zebra. It lives in the Ituri Forest in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Okapis eat the leaves and buds of trees they can reach. They also graze on grass and ferns and eat fruit. Okapis tend to be solitary animals and the mother gives birth to one offspring which continues to be dependent on the mother’s milk for six months. When they are four to five years old, they are mature and can breed, but only with other okapis.
Which of the following statements is applicable to the okapi?


- I.Okapi is a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebraII.Okapi is an herbivoreIII.Okapi is its own species




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Okapi is a herbivore (II) because it only eats plants. Okapi is a species (III) since it can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
They are not a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebra (I), even though they look like one.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
When constructing a dichotomous key for classifying bird species, which characteristic would be most appropriate for the first division in the key?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Colour of feathers
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Habitat (forest, grassland, urban)
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Presence or absence of webbed feet
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Diet (carnivorous, herbivorous, omnivorous)
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because binary traits (presence/absence) work best for early divisions in a dichotomous key.
Choice A  is incorrect because colour is too variable within a species.
Choice B  is incorrect because habitat is a variable characteristic, so not suitable for classification.
Choice D is incorrect because diet varies within species and requires direct observation.

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
Which of the following statement(s) is/are true for the genome?


- I.The genome is all the genetic information of an organism.II.Genomes within a species are identical in size.III.Genomes within a species vary in base sequence.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The genome is all the genetic information in an organism (Statement I). The base sequence can vary within a species due to single-nucleotide polymorphism (Statement III). Therefore, Choice C is correct as it contains both true statements.
Choice A is incorrect as it only includes one true statement.
The size of the genome within a species can vary, this can be due to mutations, such as insertions and deletions, so Statement II is not true. Choices B and D are, therefore, incorrect.

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
Which statement(s) below are challenges associated with the biological species concept (BSC)?


- I.The BSC assumes reproductive isolation, but some species are reproductively isolated only in certain environments.II.Fossil species cannot be assessed using the BSC due to the lack of observable mating behaviour.III.The BSC relies on morphological features, which can vary widely within a species.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because reproductive isolation may be context-dependent (e.g. due to geography or behaviour), making it unclear whether two populations are separate species under BSC.
Statement II is true because the BSC depends on observing whether organisms can interbreed. This is impossible with fossils, which are studied based on morphology and location, not reproductive behaviour.
Statement III is false because the BSC specifically does not define species based on morphology; that is the morphological species concept. BSC focuses instead on reproductive capability, so this is not a valid criticism of BSC.
Choice B is correct because it includes only the two true Statements I and II.
Choice A is incorrect as it is missing the true Statement II.
Choices C and D are incorrect as they include the false Statement III.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The following table shows the diploid chromosome number of a range of species.

OrganismDiploid chromosome numberYellow fever mosquito (Aedes egypti)6Fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster)8Spinach (Spinacia oleracea)12Carrot (Daucus carota)18Rice (Oryza sativa)24Giraffe (Giraffa camelopardalis)30Giant panda (Ailuropoda melanoleuca)42

Which of these statements is correct?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ The giant panda has more genes than the other species
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ The yellow fever mosquito has the fewest genes from these species
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ The gametes of carrots have 18 chromosomes
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ The chromosome number is a characteristic of a species
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
All species have a characteristic number of chromosomes (Choice D).
Gene number is not determined by chromosome number because chromosomes are not all the same size and do not hold the same number of genes (Choice A and Choice B). Choice C is incorrect because gametes have a haploid number of chromosomes which means gametes of carrot plants have 9 chromosomes.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
How are the chromosomes in a karyogram ordered?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ By analogous pairs
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ By number of genes
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ By size
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ By position of the centromeres
list.markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because the chromosomes in a karyogram are ordered in homologous pairs from largest to smallest.
Choice A is incorrect because chromosomes are grouped in homologous pairs (one from each parent), not analogous pairs. Choice B is incorrect because the number of genes on each chromosome is highly variable, and genes do not have a consistent length. Although the chromosomes are aligned with their centromeres in a karyogram, the question only asks about the order of the chromosomes, which is not dependent on centromere position; thus, Choice D is also incorrect.

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
The table shows the number of chromosomes found in the gametes of various species.
SpeciesHaploid chromosome number (n)Parascaris equorum (horse threadworm)2Vicia faba (field bean)6Oryza sativa (rice)12Homo sapiens (human)23Pan troglodytes (chimpanzee)24Canis familiaris (dog)39

What can be concluded from the data in the table?


- I.Diploid cells usually have an even number of chromosomes.II.Species with more chromosomes have a larger genome size.III.Humans are most closely related to Pan troglodytes.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice A is correct because diploid cells have an even number of chromosomes (Statement I) unless affected by errors such as non-disjunction. This can be obtained by doubling the haploid number in the table and recognising that an odd number of diploid chromosomes cannot be evenly distributed to form gametes.
Statement II is false because the number of chromosomes an organism has is not an accurate reflection of its genome size. Oryza sativa, for example, has a much larger genome than any of the other species in the table despite having fewer chromosomes. Statement III is false because although humans are closely related to chimpanzees, this cannot be concluded from the data in the table alone. Stipa spartea (porcupine grass), for example, has the same number of chromosomes as humans but is not closely related. Choices B, C, and D are incorrect because they contain one or more false statements.

list.title: Question 19
list.content: - Outline the different uses of karyograms. [3] - Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei. [4] - Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes. [8]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndrome OR Patau syndrome OR Klinefelter syndrome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missing OR if part of a chromosome is missing [1] [3 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Karyograms ($\checkmark$) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length ($\checkmark$). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms. Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biological male or female ($\checkmark$). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell. Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g. Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome). - Any four of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes, OR one chromosome per type WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two sets OR two chromosomes of each type [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene WHEREAS diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomes OR any other valid species example [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually gametes WHEREAS diploid cells are usually somatic cells [1] $\ce{ -> }$ haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis, WHILE diploid cells are usually the result of mitosis. [1] [4 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: Haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes($\checkmark$), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes. For example, in humans($\checkmark$), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei have one allele for each gene, ($\checkmark$) whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, only gametes($\checkmark$) have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei. - Any eight of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ (within one species) different chromosomes have different types OR different numbers of genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ both prokaryotic AND eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, WHILE eukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA, WHILE eukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH autosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development, WHILE the X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ there is only one pair of sex chromosomes, WHILE there can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species) [1] $\ce{ -> }$ autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length, WHILE two sex chromosomes can be different lengths [1] $\ce{ -> }$ chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles, WHILE non-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes [1] [8 mark maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}$: All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but they differ in length ($\checkmark$) and in the number of genes ($\checkmark$) and type of genes ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA ($\checkmark$). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes are associated with proteins ($\checkmark$). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes are linear ($\checkmark$). Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes: Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can be more than one pair of autosomes ($\checkmark$) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs are equal in length ($\checkmark$) Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes: Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes for different characteristics ($\checkmark$). list.title: Question 20
list.content: - Compare and contrast the biological species concept and the morphological concept.[3] - Explain the difficulties with applying the biological species and morphological concept to all organisms. [5] - Describe the similarities and differences within and between species. [7]
list.markScheme: - Any three of the following (students must give at least one similarity and one difference to achieve full marks): Similarities $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH concepts seek to define a species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH concepts acknowledge that there can be variation within species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ BOTH concepts are connected to the broader concept of evolution [1] Differences $\ce{ -> }$ the biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms which can interbreed to produce fertile offspring, WHEREAS the morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms with shared traits [1] $\ce{ -> }$ Mayr proposed the biological species concept WHEREAS the morphological concept was proposed by Linnaeus [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the morphological species concept was proposed before the biological species concept [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the morphological species concept is applicable to sexual and asexual organisms, WHEREAS the biological species concept is applicable only to sexually reproducing organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the biological species concept reflects the evolutionary relationship OR speciation OR gene flow, WHEREAS the morphological species concept may not represent genetic relatedness or evolutionary relationships [1] [3 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: Both concepts are used to define species ($\checkmark$), but Mayr proposed the biological species concept, whereas the morphological concept was proposed by Linnaeus ($\checkmark$). The morphological concept also came first ($\checkmark$). The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring; however, the morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms with shared traits ($\checkmark$). - Any five of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ the morphological species concept cannot be applied to species that show variation due to reproductive isolation OR the morphological concept cannot be applied to species with different forms OR polymorphism OR named example of a species with different forms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the morphological species concept does not take into account DNA OR genetic information [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the biological species concept is defined in terms of sexual reproduction HOWEVER, not all organisms reproduce sexually [1] $\ce{ -> }$ example of species that reproduce asexually, e.g. budding in yeast OR horizontal gene transfer in bacteria [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the biological species concept relies on the ability to observe and study interbreeding in real-time, which is not possible with extinct species OR fossilised organisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ some different species can interbreed and produce viable offspring, but these hybrids might have reduced fitness or be sterile, which challenges the clear-cut boundaries proposed by the biological species concept [1] $\ce{ -> }$ convergent evolution can make it difficult to accurately group organisms based solely on morphological characteristics [1] $\ce{ -> }$ rapid evolution and morphological changes in response to the environment might make individuals appear distinct, even if they share a recent common ancestor, which challenges the reliability of morphological traits as indicators of species relationships [1] [5 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring, however, not all species reproduce sexually ($\checkmark$), for example, yeast reproduce asexually by budding ($\checkmark$). It also relies on the ability to see species interbreeding, which cannot be done with extinct species or fossils ($\checkmark$). The morphological concept defines a species as a group of organisms with shared traits, however, due to variation caused by reproductive isolation and mutation, not all members of a species look the same ($\checkmark$). In addition, rapid evolution might make individuals appear distinctly related when in fact, they shared a recent common ancestor. This could make the morphological species concept less reliable ($\checkmark$). - Any seven of the following: $\ce{ -> }$ species can be defined as a group of organisms that are capable of interbreeding to produce fertile offspring [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species usually share the same number of chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species usually share identical karyotypes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ example of chromosome complement of a species, e.g. humans have 46 chromosomes [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the chromosome complement of a species can vary due to genetic conditions such as Down syndrome [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the size genome of a species can vary within a species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ the base sequence of the genome can vary within a species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ due to mutations or single-nucleotide polymorphisms [1] $\ce{ -> }$ homologous genes OR similarities in gene pathways OR similarities in the functions of genes can be found between species that share evolutionary origins [1] $\ce{ -> }$ species-specific genes are not found in other closely related species [1] $\ce{ -> }$ horizontal gene transfer between different species, often through mechanisms like viral infections or symbiotic relationships, leads to the acquisition of genes in the recipient that may not be shared by other members of the species [1] [7 marks maximum] $\underline{\textrm{Sample answer}}$: According to the biological species concept, a species can be defined as a group of organisms that are capable of interbreeding to produce fertile offspring ($\checkmark$). They can produce fertile offspring as a species usually have the same chromosome number ($\checkmark$), for example, in humans, this is 46 ($\checkmark$) unless genetic conditions such as Down syndrome affect their karyotype ($\checkmark$). The size of a species' genome can vary slightly within a species ($\checkmark$), as can the base sequence of the genome ($\checkmark$) and these are both due to mutations ($\checkmark$). list.title: Question 22
list.content:
Which of the following statements explain why classifying diverging populations as species can be arbitrary?


- I.Traits may diverge at different rates in different populationsII.Some populations may remain reproductively compatible despite divergenceIII.Morphological changes always occur before genetic differences appear




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II, and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Statement I is true because, during speciation, some traits (e.g., behaviour, physiology, morphology) can evolve faster than others. This means two populations might look different but still interbreed, or might appear similar but already be reproductively isolated. Because divergence doesn’t follow a fixed pattern, deciding when to define them as separate species becomes subjective.
Statement II is true because Populations might develop noticeable differences in traits (such as colouration or mating calls), but still produce fertile offspring when they interbreed. According to the biological species concept, they’re technically the same species, but these differences can confuse classification.
Statement III is false because often, the opposite is true. Genetic differences (mutations, allele frequency changes) may accumulate before any visible morphological change occurs. For example, two populations may look identical but carry distinct genetic markers and be reproductively isolated.
Saying morphological change “always” comes first is incorrect and overly simplistic.
Choice A is correct because it includes only the two true Statements I and II.
Choices B, C and D are incorrect as they include the false Statement III.

list.title: Question 30
list.content:
The table shows factors that can result in speciation. Which word is matched to the correct definition?

WordDefinitionA.$\hspace{1em}$PolyploidyHaving two complete sets of chromosomesB.$\hspace{1em}$Sexual reproductionThe combining of genetic information from two individualsC.$\hspace{1em}$Reproductive isolationSpecies breeding to produce infertile offspringD.$\hspace{1em}$MutationsRandom changes to the amino acid sequence
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of gametes from two individuals, resulting in offspring with a combination of genetic material. This process increases genetic variation, which is essential for evolution and natural selection. Choice B is the correct answer.
Polyploidy occurs when an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes (e.g., triploid 3n, tetraploid 4n). The definition given in the table describes diploidy (2n), which is the standard chromosome number in most sexually reproducing organisms; Choice A incorrect.
Interbreeding between different species can sometimes produce infertile offspring, such as a horse × donkey = mule. This is an example of reproductive isolation because the hybrid offspring is sterile, preventing gene flow between the two species. However, because horses and donkeys are already separate species, this does not result in speciation—it simply reinforces their reproductive barrier. For reproductive isolation to lead to speciation, it must occur within a single species, preventing interbreeding between different populations.  Choice C is incorrect.
Mutations are random changes in DNA sequences, not in the amino acid sequence; Choice D is incorrect.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
Why is the cytochrome oxidase I gene the region most commonly used for DNA barcoding in animal species?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is highly conserved, resulting in nearly identical sequences across all animal species.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is sufficiently different between species while remaining relatively constant within a species.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is found exclusively in animals and not in any other organisms.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Because this gene is part of the nuclear DNA and evolves rapidly, ensuring distinct differences even among closely related species.
list.markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice B is correct.  The cytochrome oxidase I gene has the ideal balance of variability. Its sequence differs enough between species to allow clear differentiation, yet it remains consistent within individuals of the same species. This makes it highly effective for DNA barcoding.
Choice A is incorrect: If the cytochrome oxidase I gene were too highly conserved (i.e., nearly identical across species), it wouldn’t provide enough variation to distinguish one species from another.
Choice C is incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is not exclusive to animals; it is found in the mitochondria of many eukaryotes. Its utility for animal barcoding comes from its pattern of variability, not its exclusivity.
Choice D is incorrect. The cytochrome oxidase I gene is mitochondrial, not nuclear, and its evolutionary rate is moderate rather than extremely rapid. A gene that evolves too quickly might accumulate too many mutations, complicating species-level identification.

Which of the following statements best describes how horizontal gene transfer (HGT) challenges the biological species concept in bacteria?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ HGT occurs only between closely related bacteria, reinforcing species boundaries.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ HGT is a mechanism of vertical inheritance, where genetic material is passed directly from parent to offspring.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ HGT enables bacteria to acquire genes from distantly related organisms, blurring the boundaries defined by reproductive isolation.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ HGT increases the mutation rate within a bacterial population, leading to rapid speciation.
list.markScheme:

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice C is correct because horizontal gene transfer allows bacteria to incorporate genetic material from unrelated species. This confounds the biological species concept, which relies on reproductive isolation to define species boundaries.
Choice A is incorrect because HGT is not limited to closely related bacteria; it can occur between very different bacterial species.
Choice B is incorrect as HGT is a form of lateral (non-vertical) gene transfer, not the typical parent-to-offspring inheritance.

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Why does chromosome number affect hybrid fertility?



- A.$\hspace{1em}$ Species with different chromosome numbers can always produce fertile offspring because meiosis is not affected by chromosome pairing.
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ Hybrids with mismatched chromosome numbers have increased genetic diversity, making them more fertile.
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ Chromosome number only affects physical traits, not reproductive ability.
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ Hybrids with different chromosome numbers cannot produce functional gametes because homologous chromosomes fail to pair during meiosis.
list.markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
Choice D is correct because meiosis requires homologous chromosomes to pair correctly. If the chromosome numbers do not match, pairing cannot occur properly, leading to errors in gamete formation and often resulting in sterility.
Choice A is incorrect because mismatched chromosomes disrupt meiosis, preventing successful gamete production and leading to sterility in many hybrids.
Choice B is incorrect because increased genetic diversity does not necessarily lead to higher fertility—chromosome mismatches usually cause sterility rather than increased reproductive success.
Choice C is incorrect because chromosome number directly affects meiosis and fertility.

list.content:
The following table shows the approximate number of protein-encoding genes found in various species. What can be concluded from these findings?
SpeciesApproximate number of protein-encoding genesDrosophila melanogaster (fruit fly)14,000Oryza sativa (rice)51,000Gallus gallus (chicken)20,000-23,000Homo sapiens (human)20,000-25,000


- I.The number of genes is not a good indicator of organism complexity.II.Chickens may have more genes than humans.III.The number of base pairs in the rice genome is greater than in the other species.




- A.$\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B.$\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- C.$\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- D.$\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
list.markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
The number of genes found in a species does not serve as a good indicator of complexity (Statement I). If it did, the data here would suggest that chickens and humans are equally complex, and that rice is far more complex than either of them. Due to the overlapping ranges in the number of genes, it is entirely possible for chickens to have a greater number of genes than humans (Statement II). It is impossible to determine the size of the genome (measured in base pairs) of a species based on the number of genes it has. In reality, rice has far fewer base pairs than chickens or humans despite having approximately twice as many genes (Statement III). Choice A is, therefore, correct.
Choices B, C, and D are incorrect as they all contain Statement III.
